item.title: Demystifying Multi-Agent Debate: The Role of Confidence and Diversity
item.description: arXiv:2601.19921v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Multi-agent debate (MAD) is widely used to improve large language model (LLM) performance through test-time scaling, yet recent work shows that vanilla MAD often underperforms simple majority vote despite higher computational cost. Studies show that, ...<br><br><small><strong>Source:</strong> arXiv | <strong>Keywords:</strong> model, LLM, reasoning, large language model, arxiv | <strong>Relevance:</strong> 100%</small>
item.author: noreply@contextengineering.news (arXiv)

item.title: Teaching LLMs to Ask: Self-Querying Category-Theoretic Planning for Under-Specified Reasoning
item.description: arXiv:2601.20014v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Inference-time planning with large language models frequently breaks under partial observability: when task-critical preconditions are not specified at query time, models tend to hallucinate missing facts or produce plans that violate hard constraints...<br><br><small><strong>Source:</strong> arXiv | <strong>Keywords:</strong> model, LLM, reasoning, large language model, arxiv | <strong>Relevance:</strong> 100%</small>
item.author: noreply@contextengineering.news (arXiv)

item.title: Should I Have Expressed a Different Intent? Counterfactual Generation for LLM-Based Autonomous Control
item.description: arXiv:2601.20090v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language model (LLM)-powered agents can translate high-level user intents into plans and actions in an environment. Yet after observing an outcome, users may wonder: What if I had phrased my intent differently? We introduce a framework that enab...<br><br><small><strong>Source:</strong> arXiv | <strong>Keywords:</strong> RAG, model, LLM, reasoning, framework | <strong>Relevance:</strong> 100%</small>
item.author: noreply@contextengineering.news (arXiv)
